message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Robust Time-Varying Formation Control of One-Sided Lipschitz Nonlinear Multiagent System With Delays via Optimization Algorithm
Paper Abstract: This article develops a novel robust control methodology for nonlinear multiagent systems (MASs) to address the time-varying formation (TVF) problem. The methodology offers a concise yet efficacious technique based on the Lyapunov functional for more general one-sided Lipschitz (OSL) nonlinear MASs with external disturbances and time-varying delays. Note that most existing TVF controllers can only achieve formation targets under small delays, which significantly limits their performance. The proposed TVF control method in this article demonstrates remarkable robustness by effectively accommodating larger delays and additionally mitigating the impact of disturbances on MASs. On this basis, a robust TVF controller optimization scheme of MASs combined with the particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm is proposed. Comparing the optimized results with those under conventional control methods, it has been proved that optimized controller has obvious improvement on the formation performance of MASs. Finally, the feasibility and the superiority of the developed TVF control approach are validated by a simulation of an autonomous aerial vehicle swarm system (AAVSS) composed of six AAVs.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about autonomous aerial vehicles:

## Definition

An autonomous aircraft is an aircraft which flies under the control of on-board autonomous robotic systems and needs no intervention from a human pilot or remote control.

## Related Terminology

Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), commonly known as drones, are aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, controlled remotely or autonomously.(no content)Unmanned aerial vehicles include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs).

## Technologies and Capabilities

Autonomous drones employ advanced technologies such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors to carry out their missions without human intervention.(no content)Specific autonomous operations include self-level (attitude stabilization), altitude hold, hover/position hold, and take-off and landing.

## Applications

Aerial autonomous logistics provide transfer of resources and equipment in disaster relief situations, replenishment operations, reconnaissance operations, and general parcel or package delivery. Additionally, a personal air vehicle is typically understood to be an autonomous electric aircraft with point-to-point VTOL capability.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Personal air vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_air_vehicle"},{"title":"Autonomous logistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_logistics"},{"title":"Automated aerial refueling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_aerial_refueling"},{"title":"Pegaz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pegaz"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Osica (drone) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osica_(drone)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about autonomous aerial vehicles:

## Definition

An autonomous aircraft is an aircraft which flies under the control of on-board autonomous robotic systems and needs no intervention from a human pilot or remote control.

## Related Terminology

Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), commonly known as drones, are aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, controlled remotely or autonomously.(no content)Unmanned aerial vehicles include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs).

## Technologies and Capabilities

Autonomous drones employ advanced technologies such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors to carry out their missions without human intervention.(no content)Specific autonomous operations include self-level (attitude stabilization), altitude hold, hover/position hold, and take-off and landing.

## Applications

Aerial autonomous logistics provide transfer of resources and equipment in disaster relief situations, replenishment operations, reconnaissance operations, and general parcel or package delivery. Additionally, a personal air vehicle is typically understood to be an autonomous electric aircraft with point-to-point VTOL capability.

Web search results for query: "Multiagent system"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Agent-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_software_engineering"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multiagent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Key Capabilities

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Structure and Components

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Important Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have several important features: Autonomy: agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous. Local views: no agent has a full global view, or the system is too complex for an agent to exploit such knowledge. Decentralization: no agent is designated as controlling (or the system is effectively reduced to a monolithic system).

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Web search results for query: "Particle swarm optimization"

Links: [{"title":"Particle swarm optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particle_swarm_optimization"},{"title":"Multi-swarm optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-swarm_optimization"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Swarm behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_behaviour"},{"title":"Maurice Clerc (mathematician) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Clerc_(mathematician)"}]

Here are the search results for **Particle Swarm Optimization**:

## Overview

Particle swarm optimization (PSO) is a computational method that optimizes a problem by iteratively trying to improve a population of candidate solutions with regard to a given measure of quality.(no content)It solves a problem through interactions among a population of candidate solutions, dubbed particles, moving the particles around in the search-space according to simple mathematical formulae that adjust each particle's position and velocity.

## How It Works

Each particle's movement is influenced by its own best known position so far, and by the best known position in its topological neighborhood (which may include the entire population if so specified); vectors are updated as better positions are found.

## Origins

PSO was developed in 1995 by Kennedy and Eberhart and was first aimed at simulating the social behaviour and choreography of bird flocks and fish schools.

## Key Characteristics

PSO is a metaheuristic as it makes few or no assumptions about the problem being optimized and can search very large spaces of candidate solutions.(no content)PSO does not use the gradient of the problem being optimized, which means PSO does not require that the optimization problem be differentiable as is required by classic optimization methods such as gradient descent and quasi-newton methods.

However, metaheuristics such as PSO do not guarantee an optimal solution is ever found.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Robust control"

Links: [{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"Nichols plot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nichols_plot"},{"title":"Minor loop feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minor_loop_feedback"},{"title":"Keith Glover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keith_Glover"},{"title":"Power to the edge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_to_the_edge_(management_technique)"},{"title":"Youla–Kucera parametrization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youla–Kucera_parametrization"},{"title":"Innovative Vector Control Consortium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovative_Vector_Control_Consortium"}]

Here are the search results for "Robust control":

## Overview

Robust control refers to theory of feedback regulation that began taking shape in the late 1970's and onwards, where modeling uncertainty is explicitly acknowledged, modeled, and taken into account in control design.

## Key Concepts

An essential part of any feedback control scheme is tolerance to modeling uncertainty—the ability to maintain a satisfactory level of performance when the system dynamics deviate from the nominal value used in the design. The ability of a feedback control system to maintain stability and performance under uncertainty is referred to as robustness.(no content)Informally, a controller designed for a particular set of model parameters is said to be robust if it also works well for values of the parameters near the nominal.

## Historical Development

The term robust control was not used until the 1980's when modern methods started being developed to optimize for parametric and non-parametric modeling uncertainty.(no content)The term robust control became almost synonymous with the term H-infinity control, since it was the techniques in the development of the latter that gave the early impetus for the new methods.

## Types of Uncertainty

Parametric uncertainty refers to the case where modeling parameters or external disturbances in feedback regulation are expected to be found within some (typically compact) set of a finite dimensional space. Robust control aims to achieve robust performance and stability in the presence of such bounded modeling errors.(no content)Non-parametric uncertainty refers to the case where the magnitude of expected modeling errors and disturbances is quantified via metrics on function spaces where these reside (infinite dimensional).

Here are the search results for "Robust control":

## Overview

Robust control refers to theory of feedback regulation that began taking shape in the late 1970's and onwards, where modeling uncertainty is explicitly acknowledged, modeled, and taken into account in control design.

## Key Concepts

An essential part of any feedback control scheme is tolerance to modeling uncertainty—the ability to maintain a satisfactory level of performance when the system dynamics deviate from the nominal value used in the design. The ability of a feedback control system to maintain stability and performance under uncertainty is referred to as robustness.(no content)Informally, a controller designed for a particular set of model parameters is said to be robust if it also works well for values of the parameters near the nominal.

## Historical Development

The term robust control was not used until the 1980's when modern methods started being developed to optimize for parametric and non-parametric modeling uncertainty.(no content)The term robust control became almost synonymous with the term H-infinity control, since it was the techniques in the development of the latter that gave the early impetus for the new methods.

## Types of Uncertainty

Parametric uncertainty refers to the case where modeling parameters or external disturbances in feedback regulation are expected to be found within some (typically compact) set of a finite dimensional space. Robust control aims to achieve robust performance and stability in the presence of such bounded modeling errors.(no content)Non-parametric uncertainty refers to the case where the magnitude of expected modeling errors and disturbances is quantified via metrics on function spaces where these reside (infinite dimensional).

I've completed a web search for "Nonlinear systems control". Here's a summary of what I found:

## Overview

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Characteristics

These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations. The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems.(no content)These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.

## Analysis and Design Approaches

Nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language. Additionally, if only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.

## Advanced Techniques

Some notable control strategies for nonlinear systems include:

- Feedback linearization is a common strategy employed in nonlinear control to control nonlinear systems.
- Nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) is a variant of model predictive control that is characterized by the use of nonlinear system models in the prediction, and requires the iterative solution of optimal control problems on a finite prediction horizon.
- Input-to-state stability (ISS) is a stability notion widely used to study stability of nonlinear control systems with external inputs.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov function stability"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"},{"title":"Chetaev instability theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chetaev_instability_theorem"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Lyapunov function stability:

## Definition and Purpose

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Core Concept

The fundamental idea behind Lyapunov functions is elegant. Lyapunov's realization was that stability can be proven without requiring knowledge of the true physical energy, provided a Lyapunov function can be found to satisfy the above constraints. In essence, a Lyapunov function is a nonnegative scalar measure of a multi-dimensional state, and typically the function is defined to grow large when the system moves towards undesirable states.

## Stability Conditions

If the equilibrium point is isolated, the Lyapunov-candidate-function is locally positive definite, and the time derivative of the Lyapunov-candidate-function is locally negative definite, then the equilibrium is proven to be locally asymptotically stable.(no content)Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium (within a distance) remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Applications and Extensions

For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability. Whereas there is no general technique for constructing Lyapunov functions for ODEs, in many specific cases the construction of Lyapunov functions is known.(no content)ISS unified the Lyapunov and input-output stability theories and revolutionized views on stabilization of nonlinear systems, design of robust nonlinear observers, stability of nonlinear interconnected control systems, nonlinear detectability theory, and supervisory adaptive control.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the web search results, here are the main meanings and contexts for "Formation control":

## Robotics and Multi-Agent Systems

Formation control of robotic systems is a field of research involving the coordinated control of multiple robots. This is an active area in robotics engineering where researchers develop algorithms and methods to coordinate movements and positioning of groups of autonomous agents or robots.

## Oil and Gas Industry

In the petroleum industry, oil well control involves preventing the formation gas or fluid (hydrocarbons) from entering into the wellbore during drilling or well interventions. This is a critical safety procedure in drilling operations.

## Other Potential Meanings

The search results also returned several other interpretations of "control" in different contexts (management control, control theory, linguistic control, etc.), but these are general control concepts rather than "formation control" specifically.

The most prominent technical use of the term "formation control" appears to be in the field of robotics and autonomous systems, where it refers to coordinating the movement and positioning of multiple agents to maintain specific geometric formations.

Based on the web search results, here are the main meanings and contexts for "Formation control":

## Robotics and Multi-Agent Systems

Formation control of robotic systems is a field of research involving the coordinated control of multiple robots. This is an active area in robotics engineering where researchers develop algorithms and methods to coordinate movements and positioning of groups of autonomous agents or robots.

## Oil and Gas Industry

In the petroleum industry, oil well control involves preventing the formation gas or fluid (hydrocarbons) from entering into the wellbore during drilling or well interventions. This is a critical safety procedure in drilling operations.

## Other Potential Meanings

The search results also returned several other interpretations of "control" in different contexts (management control, control theory, linguistic control, etc.), but these are general control concepts rather than "formation control" specifically.

The most prominent technical use of the term "formation control" appears to be in the field of robotics and autonomous systems, where it refers to coordinating the movement and positioning of multiple agents to maintain specific geometric formations.

Links: [{"title":"Lipschitz continuity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lipschitz_continuity"},{"title":"Continuous function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_function"},{"title":"Talk:Lipschitz continuity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Lipschitz_continuity"},{"title":"Lipschitz domain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lipschitz_domain"},{"title":"Uniform continuity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_continuity"},{"title":"Absolute continuity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_continuity"},{"title":"Hölder condition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H%C3%B6lder_condition"},{"title":"Bounded operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounded_linear_operator"},{"title":"Rudolf Lipschitz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolf_Lipschitz"},{"title":"Dini test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dini_test"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about Lipschitz continuity:

## Definition

A function f : X → Y between two metric spaces is called Lipschitz continuous if there exists a real constant K ≥ 0 such that, for all x₁ and x₂ in X, the distance between f(x₁) and f(x₂) is bounded by K times the distance between x₁ and x₂.(no content)Any such K is referred to as a Lipschitz constant for the function f.(no content)If K = 1 the function is called a short map, and if 0 ≤ K < 1 and f maps a metric space to itself, the function is called a contraction.

## Properties and Relationships

Every Lipschitz continuous map is uniformly continuous.(no content)Every Lipschitz-continuous function is absolutely continuous.(no content)For functions over a closed and bounded interval of the real line, we have: Continuously differentiable ⊂ Lipschitz continuous ⊂ absolutely continuous ⊂ uniformly continuous ⊂ continuous.

## Characterization and Examples

An everywhere differentiable function is Lipschitz continuous (with K = sup |g′(x)|) if and only if it has a bounded first derivative.(no content)The function f(x) = x² with domain all real numbers is not Lipschitz continuous because the function becomes arbitrarily steep as x approaches infinity, though it is locally Lipschitz continuous.

## Applications

In differential equations, Lipschitz continuity is the central condition of the Picard–Lindelöf theorem which guarantees the existence and uniqueness of the solution to an initial value problem.(no content)A special type of Lipschitz continuity, called contraction, is used in the Banach fixed-point theorem.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence).

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Robust Time-Varying Formation Control of One-Sided Lipschitz Nonlinear Multiagent System With Delays via Optimization Algorithm". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Contribution (the paper proposes a novel robust control methodology)

**Key Entities Identified:** 7 triples extracted and validated

### Proposed Technology:
- **Robust control** (method) - The paper proposes a novel robust time-varying formation control methodology specifically designed to accommodate larger delays and mitigate disturbances in nonlinear multiagent systems.

### Technologies Used:
1. **Lyapunov function** (method) - Core mathematical technique for stability analysis
2. **Particle swarm optimization** (method) - Algorithm for optimizing control parameters
3. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - Framework for the coordinated control problem
4. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (task) - Application domain validated through autonomous aerial vehicle swarm simulations
5. **Nonlinear control** (concept) - Addresses one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear systems
6. **Lipschitz continuity** (concept) - Mathematical property defining the system class

All triples have been verified with Wikipedia URLs and the validation has passed successfully.

Sources:
- [Lyapunov function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function)
- [Particle swarm optimization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particle_swarm_optimization)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Robust control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control)
- [Unmanned aerial vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle)
- [Nonlinear control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control)
- [Lipschitz continuity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lipschitz_continuity)
